sen.j: 武家屋敷（ぶけやしき）は主に江戸時代の江戸に大名が所有した出張所を兼ねた大名の邸宅。
sen.e: "Buke Yashiki" is typically a mansion which daimyo (a provincial lord) kept in Edo as a second house and as a branch office as well in Edo Period.
A "Buke Yashiki" is typically a mansion which a daimyo (provincial lord) kept in Edo as a second house and as a branch office in the Edo Period.
A "Buke Yashiki" is typically a mansion which a daimyo (provincial lord) kept in Edo as a second house and as a branch office in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: period 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 大名屋敷のこと。
sen.e: It is also called Daimyo Yashiki (daimyo residence).
It is also called Daimyo Yashiki (daimyo residence).
It is also called Daimyo Yashiki (daimyo residence).

sen.j: 藩邸とも。
sen.e: It was also called ''Hantei".
It was also called ''Hantei".
It was also called ''Hantei".

sen.j: 対義語に公家屋敷がある。
sen.e: Its antonym is Kuge Yashiki (residence of a court noble).
Its antonym is Kuge Yashiki (residence of a court noble).
Its antonym is Kuge Yashiki (residence of a court noble).

sen.j: 現在の解釈では、主に近世の武士の住まいである侍屋敷のことも含まれている。
sen.e: Today's definition of it also covers "Samurak Yashiki" which was a residence of samurai after Sengoku Period.
Today's definition also covers "Samurai Yashiki" which was a residence of samurai after the Sengoku Period.
Today's definition also covers "Samurai Yashiki" which was a residence of samurai after the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: 戦国時代の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 大名屋敷（だいみょうやしき）は、その大名が仕える主人の屋敷や城の近くや内側に構えた屋敷、大名が職務・居住のみを問わず構えた屋敷である。
sen.e: "Daimyo Yashiki" is a residence of a master whom daimyo served, a residence daimyo kept inside or outside the castle, or a mansion daimyo kept regardless of his work or residency.
"Daimyo Yashiki" refers to the residence of a master served by a daimyo, a residence daimyo kept inside or outside a castle, or a residence daimyo separate from their place of work or habitation.
"Daimyo Yashiki" refers to the residence of a master served by a daimyo, a residence daimyo kept inside or outside a castle, or a residence daimyo kept regardless of his place of work or habitation.

sen.j: 人質を住まわせるための施設や天下普請のための宿舎と工事事務所を意味していることもあった。
sen.e: It sometimes meant a facility to keep hostages or to accommodate workers and offices for public construction work.
It sometimes referred to a building where hostages were kept, or one to accommodate workers and offices for public construction work.
sen.cmt: 「meant a facility to keep hostages」→「referred to a building where hostages were kept,」, 「one」挿入
sen.e: It sometimes referred to a building where hostages were kept, or one to accommodate workers and offices for public construction work.

sen.j: 文禄・慶長の役の際に名護屋城に造られた大名陣屋等もそれに含まれる。
sen.e: Its definition also includes Daimyo Jinya (fortified house for battles) that was built at Nagoya-jo Castle (in Saga Prefecture) at the wars of Bunroku-Keicho no Eki (wars initiated by invasion of Korean Peninsula by Hideyoshi's army in 1592 through 1598).

The definition also includes the Daimyo Jinya (fortified house) that was built at Nagoya-jo Castle (in Saga Prefecture) during the wars of Bunroku-Keicho no Eki (wars initiated by the invasion of the Korean Peninsula by Hideyoshi's army in 1592 through 1598).

The definition also includes the Daimyo Jinya (fortified house) that was built at Nagoya-jo Castle (in Saga Prefecture) during the Bunroku-Keicho War (wars initiated by the invasion of the Korean Peninsula by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's army in 1592 through 1598).
sen.cmt: Bunroku-Keicho War としました。 括弧内は削除しました。

tit.cmt: period 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 江戸時代においては、大名が幕府より土地を与えられて江戸城近辺や郊外に構えたもの、また、各大名の事情により大坂や京都にも構えられた。
sen.e: In Edo Period, Bakufu (Shogunate) provided Daimyo with some lands in the neighborhood of Edo-jo Castle or in the suburban areas where daimyo built their houses, and also they kept residences in Osaka or in Kyoto for their own convenience.

In the Edo Period, the Bakufu (Shogunate) provided Daimyo with land in the neighborhood of Edo-jo Castle or in suburban areas where daimyo built their houses, and they also kept residences in Osaka or in Kyoto for their own convenience.

In the Edo period, the Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) provided Daimyo with land in the neighborhood of Edo-jo Castle or in suburban areas where daimyo built their houses, and they also kept residences in Osaka or in Kyoto for their own convenience.
sen.cmt: 幕府の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 江戸の大名屋敷は、その大名が参勤交代で江戸に滞在する間に居住し、また、現在の大使館のような役割を持ち、大名（藩）の幕府への政治的、経済的な窓口としても機能した。
sen.e: DaimyoYashiki in Edo was a place where daimyo stayed during his term of Sankinkotai (duty of alternate-year attendancein Edo), and also had an embassy-like function for daimyo (han, or his domain) to make political or economical negotiations with Bakufu.

Daimyo Yashiki in Edo were places where daimyo stayed during their term of Sankinkotai (duty of alternate-year attendance in Edo), and they also had an embassy-like function for daimyo (han, or his domain) for political or economical negotiations with the Bakufu.
sen.cmt: 「DaimyoYashiki」→「Daimyo Yashiki」,「was a place」→「were places」,「his」→「their」, 「they」挿入,「to make」→「for」, 「the」挿入
sen.e: Daimyo Yashiki in Edo were places where daimyo stayed during their term of Sankinkotai (duty of alternate-year attendance in Edo), and they also had an embassy-like function for daimyo (han, or his domain) for political or economical negotiations with the Bakufu.

sen.j: 江戸における大名屋敷
sen.e: DaimyoYashiki in Edo
Daimyo Yashiki in Edo
Daimyo Yashiki in Edo

sen.j: 江戸の大名屋敷には、上屋敷・中屋敷・下屋敷等といい幕府から与えられて所有、活用していた。
sen.e: Bakufu provided daimyo with Kami (upper) Yashiki, Naka (middle) Yashiki, and Shimo (lower) Yashiki to own and use them.
The Bakufu provided daimyo with Kami (upper) Yashiki, Naka (middle) Yashiki, and Shimo (lower) Yashiki to own and use.
The Bakufu provided daimyo with Kami (upper) Yashiki, Naka (middle) Yashiki, and Shimo (lower) Yashiki to own and use.

sen.j: 上屋敷、中屋敷、下屋敷の上中下の違いは、江戸城からの距離で区別されたものである。
sen.e: Kami, Naka, and Shimo were distinguished by the distances from Edo-jo Castle.
Kami, Naka, and Shimo were distinguished by their distance from Edo-jo Castle.
Kami, Naka, and Shimo were distinguished by their distance from Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 元文3年（1738年）には大名の禄高（石高）によって敷地面積の標準が定められていたが、上屋敷のもののみであり、実際はそれに準じなかった。
sen.e: In 1738, the standard area of only Kami Yashiki was set according to daimyo's Rokudaka (stipend assessed on the basis of the crop yield of a dainyo's domain), but actually the total area did not conform to it.

In 1738, the standard area of Kami Yashiki was set according to the daimyo's Rokudaka (stipend assessed on the basis of the crop yield of a daimyo's domain), but in practice the total area did not conform to it.

In 1738, the standard area of Kami Yashiki was set according to the daimyo's Rokudaka (stipend assessed on the basis of the crop yield of a daimyo's domain), but in practice the total area did not conform to it.

sen.j: 主に、江戸城近辺の大名とその家族が居住する上屋敷と、より私的な空間である下屋敷のふたつを使い分けていた。
sen.e: Daimyo and his family lived in his Kami Yashiki and he used Shimo Yashiki as his private space.
The daimyo and his family lived in his Kami Yashiki and he used Shimo Yashiki as his private space.
The daimyo and his family lived in his Kami Yashiki and he used Shimo Yashiki as his private space.

sen.j: 大名の中にはそれらの中間に中屋敷を設けたものもあった。
sen.e: Some daimyo held Naka Yashiki in the middle.
Some daimyo held Naka Yashiki in the middle.
Some daimyo held Naka Yashiki in the middle.

sen.j: （詳細は江戸藩邸を参照のこと）
sen.e: (Refer to 'Edo Hantei.')
(Refer to 'Edo Hantei.')
(Refer to 'Edo Hantei.')

sen.j: 蔵屋敷は下屋敷の一つで、敷地内には、複数の蔵と屋敷があり、海岸や河口に造られ、国元で造られた品を江戸へ荷揚げし、払い下げるか売り下げて、市場に送り出す施設として使われた。
sen.e: Kura Yashiki, a kind of Shimo Yashiki, had several warehouses and residences in the compound built at a seaside or at a river mouth, and they were facilities for distribution of the products of daimyo's home domain to discharge them in Edo, and to put them into the market for disposal prices.

Kura Yashiki, a kind of Shimo Yashiki, had several warehouses and residences in the compound which was built on the coast or at the mouth of a river, and these were facilities for the distribution of the products of the daimyo's home domain to transport them to Edo, and to put them into the market for disposal.
sen.cmt: 「built at a seaside or at a river mouth」→「which was built on the coast or at the mouth of a river」, 「they」→「these」, 「the」挿入x2,「discharge them in」→「transport them to」,「prices」削除
sen.e: Kura Yashiki, a kind of Shimo Yashiki, had several warehouses and residences in the compound which was built on the coast or at the mouth of a river, and these were facilities for the distribution of the products of the daimyo's home domain to transport them to Edo, and to put them into the market for disposal.
sen.cmt: 二バイト文字を修正しました。

sen.j: 主に経済的活動のための施設である。
sen.e: They were mainly used for economical activities.
They were mainly used for economic activities.
They were mainly used for economic activities.

sen.j: （詳細は蔵屋敷を参照のこと）
sen.e: (Refer to "Kura Yashiki" for details.)
(Refer to "Kura Yashiki" for details.)
(Refer to "Kura Yashiki" for details.)

sen.j: 侍屋敷（さむらいやしき）は、下級武士の住まう邸宅のことである。
sen.e: "Samurai Yashiki" were residences for low ranked samurai.
"Samurai Yashiki" were residences for low ranked samurai.
"Samurai Yashiki" were residences for low ranked samurai.

sen.j: 中世までは武士はそれぞれの領地に住んでいたが、近世になり兵農分離が行われると、城下町に集まって住むよう強制された。
sen.e: Samurai used to live in their local domains in the medieval period, but after Sengoku Period soldiers did not have to farm and they were forced to live in castle towns leaving their farmlands.
Samurai used to live in their local domains in the medieval period, but after the Sengoku Period soldiers did not need to farm and were forced to live in castle towns leaving their farmlands behind.
Samurai used to live in their local domains in the medieval period, but after the Sengoku period soldiers did not need to farm and were forced to live in castle towns leaving their farmlands behind.
sen.cmt: period 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 現在の公務員の宿舎に近いものである。
sen.e: It was a kind of housing for government workers of today.
It was similar to housing for government workers today.
It was similar to housing for government workers today.

sen.j: 侍屋敷が集まったものを侍町という。
sen.e: "Samurai-machi" was an area where Samurai Yashiki were congregated.
"Samurai-machi" was an area where many Samurai Yashiki were built.
"Samurai-machi" was an area where many Samurai Yashiki were built.

sen.j: 侍町は城郭を中心に防御することを意識して計画的に配置される。
sen.e: Samurai-machi were built as planned to mainly defend the castle structure.
Samurai-machi were purposefully built in order to defend the castle structure.
sen.cmt: 「built as planned to mainly」→「purposefully built in order to」
sen.e: Samurai-machi were purposefully built in order to defend the castle structure.

sen.j: 城を持つ地域では、その城によって三の丸や外郭内を侍町とすることがあった。
sen.e: In castle towns, some castles had Samurai-machi in their Sannomaru (outer area of a castle) or inside the outer castle walls.
In castle towns, some castles had Samurai-machi in their Sannomaru (outer area of a castle) or inside the outer castle walls.
In castle towns, some castles had Samurai-machi in their Sannomaru (outer area of a castle) or inside the outer castle walls.

sen.j: 陣屋の地域では、陣屋の敷地内に小規模な侍屋敷を構えて住まわせることもあった。
sen.e: In jinya areas, they had small scale samurai yashiki inside jinya compounds.
In jinya areas, they had small scale samurai yashiki inside jinya compounds.
In jinya (regional government office) areas, they had small scale samurai yashiki inside jinya compounds.
sen.cmt: 陣屋の説明を記載しました。

sen.j: 旗本や御家人などの一般の武士の住まいは民家とそれほど変わらない規模の建物であったことも多いが、上級や中級の侍屋敷では土塀や長屋門、式台を構え、下級のものも少なくとも書院造の座敷を設けるなど、格を示すような特徴を持っていた。
sen.e: Although many ordinary samurai such as Hatamoto (direct retainers of shogun) or Gokenin (lower-ranked vassals) had residences as large as folk houses, upper or middle class Samurai Yashiki had mud walls, Nagayamon (a gate and long house for vassals), and Shikidai (an entrance hall of wood floor), and even lower class ones had at least zashiki (a tatami-mat reception room) of Shoin-zukuri (a typical traditional Japanese style house), trying to hold high status.

Although many ordinary samurai such as Hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) or Gokenin (lower-ranked vassals) had residences which differed little from folk houses, upper or middle class Samurai Yashiki had mud walls, Nagayamon (a gate and long house for vassals), and Shikidai (an entrance hall with a wooden floor), and even lower class ones had at least zashiki (a tatami-mat reception room) of Shoin-zukuri style (a typical traditional Japanese style house), attempting to display their high status.
sen.cmt: 「the」挿入,「as large as」→「which differed little from」, 「of wood」→「with a wooden」,「style」挿入,「trying to hold」→「attempting to display their」
sen.e: Although many ordinary samurai such as Hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) or Gokenin (lower-ranked vassals) had residences which differed little from folk houses, upper or middle class Samurai Yashiki had mud walls, Nagayamon (a gate and long house for vassals), and Shikidai (an entrance hall with a wooden floor), and even lower class ones had at least zashiki (a tatami-mat reception room) of Shoin-zukuri style (a typical traditional Japanese style house), attempting to display their high status.

sen.j: また、江戸時代は、社家も士族に準じる身分・格式とされ、屋敷の様式も、概ね武士の屋敷に準じるものである。
sen.e: In Edo Period, because Shake (Shinto priest families) had the rank and status similar to that of samurai class, generally so did their residences.
In the Edo Period, because Shake (Shinto priest families) had the rank and status similar to that of the samurai class, their residences were also similar.
sen.cmt: 「the」挿入x2, 「generally so did their residences」→「their residences were also similar」
sen.e: In the Edo period, because Shake (Shinto priest families) had the rank and status similar to that of the samurai class, their residences were also similar.
sen.cmt: period 小文字にしました。

tit.j: 武家屋敷（侍屋敷）の街並み・社家町
tit.e: Townscapes of Buke Yashiki (Samurai Yashiki) and Shake-machi (Shake town)
Townscapes of Buke Yashiki (Samurai Yashiki) and Shake-machi (Shake towns)
Townscapes of Buke Yashiki (Samurai Yashiki) and Shake-machi (Shake towns)

sen.j: 維新によって役目を失った侍屋敷は多くが破却され、また戦災や戦後の都市開発によって失われた。
sen.e: Meiji Restoration made Samurai Yashiki useless and many of them were dismantled, and also the Second World War and the urban development after the war brought down most of them.
The Meiji Restoration made Samurai Yashiki redundant and many of them were dismantled, and the Second World War and the urban development which followed it caused most of them to be destroyed.
The Meiji Restoration made Samurai Yashiki redundant and many of them were dismantled, and the Second World War and the urban development which followed it caused most of them to be destroyed.

sen.j: しかし侍屋敷、侍町の佇まいを現在に伝える地域もあり、その一部は重要伝統的建造物群保存地区に選定されている。
sen.e: However, some Samurai Yashiki or Samurai-machi areas survive today to keep their old appearances, and some of them are designated as Important Preservation Districts for Groups of Historic Buildings.
However, some Samurai Yashiki or Samurai-machi areas survive today in the form they once held, and some of them are designated as Important Preservation Districts for Groups of Historic Buildings.
sen.cmt: 「to keep their old appearances」→「in the form they once held」
sen.e: However, some Samurai Yashiki or Samurai-machi areas survive today in the form they once held, and some of them are designated as Important Preservation Districts for Groups of Historic Buildings.

sen.e: There is a house called "Bukeyashiki" in Higashiiya of Miyoshi City, Tokushima Prefecture, which has a legend of survivors of Taira family (its exterior appears to be a farmhouse).
